Expectation1: Respond to emails and messages within a reasonable time frame
Situation1: Leadership needs a prompt reply to confirm details for an external partner.
Situation2: They notice swimmers occasionally entering the shallow area without supervision.
Story: I sat at my desk, the pool’s chlorine tang still clinging to my skin from my morning shift. My phone buzzed with a message from my manager: “Need your confirmation for the partner meeting—please reply ASAP.” I glanced at the clock. I had promised to check my emails during my break, but the pool was busy, and I was the only lifeguard on duty. Out of the corner of my eye, I saw a group of kids edging into the shallow end, unsupervised. My heart pounded. If I left my post for even a minute to send that email, I’d be breaking the cardinal rule of lifeguarding—never leave swimmers unattended. But if I didn’t reply, I’d be letting my team down, risking the partnership we’d worked so hard to build. The weight of both roles pressed on me, each demanding my full attention, each with consequences I couldn’t ignore. I stood frozen, torn between the urgent ping of my phone and the watchful gaze I owed the pool.
